subject: chemistry
title: Chemical Reactions
description: Discover how atoms and molecules interact in chemical reactions, including combustion, synthesis, and decomposition.

labSteps.title: Reactants and Products
labSteps.instruction: Observe hydrogen and oxygen molecules (reactants) before the reaction. Tap each molecule to identify it.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Distinguish reactants from products in a chemical equation.

labSteps.title: Bond Breaking
labSteps.instruction: Chemical reactions start when existing bonds break. Drag the molecules together to start the reaction.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Understand that energy is required to break bonds.

labSteps.title: Bond Formation
labSteps.instruction: New bonds form to create products (H₂O). Rotate to see the water molecules forming.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Understand that energy is released when new bonds form.

labSteps.title: Conservation of Mass
labSteps.instruction: Count atoms on both sides of the reaction. The total number of atoms is conserved — matter is neither created nor destroyed.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Apply the law of conservation of mass to chemical equations.

questions.question: In a chemical reaction, reactants are:
options: Catalysts that speed up the reaction
questions.explanation: Reactants are the starting materials in a chemical reaction. They are transformed into products during the reaction.

questions.question: What law states that atoms are neither created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction?
questions.explanation: The Law of Conservation of Mass states that the total mass of reactants equals the total mass of products in a chemical reaction.

questions.question: What type of reaction combines two substances to form one product?
questions.explanation: A synthesis reaction combines two or more substances to form a single, more complex product (A + B → AB).

questions.question: In the reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, how many total hydrogen atoms are on the left side?
questions.explanation: 2H₂ means two molecules of hydrogen, each with 2 hydrogen atoms, giving 2×2 = 4 hydrogen atoms on the left side.
